div1.p: Ferris reports on the yellow fever situation in Ouidah (Africa).

div1.head: English translation [from French] of letter from [s.n.] Ferris to the Chief of the Health Service (Porto-Novo), July 13, 1923
div1.opener:
Ouida
#2
TRANSLATED FROM THE FRENCH
GENERAL GOVERNMENT OF
FRENCH WEST AFRICA
Porto-Novo, July 13, 1923
-----------
DAHOMEY COLONY
HEALTH SERVICE
The Chief of the Health Service
To the Lieutenant-Governor at Porto-Novo.
div1.p:
I have the honor to report the results of the inquiry prescribed by
the Colonial Minister on the origin of the yellow fever cases at Ouidah.

Every idea of importation by the European element can be completely
rejected. The persons attacked had been at Ouidah a long time and had not
traveled. They must therefore have been infected on the spot. Officer Lefur
was the only one who had recently arrived in the Colony, but he came from
the Ivory Coast which has not been contaminated, and had been at Ouidah since
May 18th. He first showed signs of fatigue on the 5th or 6th of June and
died on the 10th of June. For that matter he was only the third person attacked.

The view of the accidental infection by sea or air route of the
European element cannot be maintained. As Dr. Valmorin remarks in his report,
Ouidah's sea connections with other colonies are very limited and do not
admit the view of a possible infection of European origin. By land the only
regular communication is with Togo and Nigeria. It is hardly possible for
a European coming from the Gold Coast or Nigeria to make so short a stay at
Dahomey that he will pass unnoticed if he has yellow fever symptoms. The
question must be examined from an entirely different angle, as far as the
natives are concerned. But first of all we must mention a view accepted with-
out discussion as a dogma, that African races are entirely immune to yellow
fever. This has been generally admitted up to the present, perhaps due to
insufficient observation and lack of information on what goes on among the
natives. As a matter of fact in Dr. Valmorin's report we note a very interesting
- 2 -
fact which should receive attention, although it did not receive any medical
observation, the suspicious case of a child that died on the third day of its
illness after having vomited blood. Furthermore, two cases of yellow fever
among natives reported recently at Cape Coast by the English Gold Coast author-
ities.

The opinion given by the Inspector General of the Health Service of
West Africa, in his note of August 28th, 1922, to the effect that European cases
are only the visible links in a yellow fever chain, these links being closely
bound together by unnoticed cases among the natives, is not mere supposition.

The immunity of African races living in endemic centers, is in all
probability an acquired, incomplete and temporary immunity that is continually
renewed.

The two cases reported from the Gold Coast warrant the assertion that
yellow fever can, without doubt, exist among natives.

On my visit to Ouidah on June 8th, I already had this possible origin
of yellow fever in mind. Nothing suspicious from the point of view of mortality
had been noted by the Commander of the settlement or the Doctor in Chief of the
post. Following departmental instructions, a very careful investigation gave
no further light on the subject. It is not very likely on the other hand, that
the epidemic originated on the spot. Yellow fever had not appeared at Ouidah
for many years and when Anecho and Grand-Popo were considered endemic centers,
Ouidah was considered free.

It is therefore natural to suppose that an epidemic of yellow fever
was created at Ouidah through some unnoticed connection with natives. As Dr.
Valmorin remarks, control in this direction is almost impossible. After the
appearance in June 1922 of a case of yellow fever and one European death at
Grand-Popo, and another European case at Anecho, yellow fever so to speak did
- 3 -
not cease to exist on the Gulf of Guinea, and the contamination doubtless was
brought on through the intermediary of natives, because the different colonies
have constant contact with each other by land routes immune from surveillance.

Unfortunately life among the natives is too much beyond our control
for us to be posted on this subject from a medical point of view.

The cases notes by Dr. Trautmann at Cotonou are interesting and worthy
of laboratory study. They do not however appear to have any connection with
yellow fever. During April of this year I myself had an opportunity to note
together with Dr. Trautmann ten similar cases which had occurred in the same
circumstances and among natives from the same place.

Because of the fear that these might have been cases of ictero-
hemorrhagic fever, they were even isolated in the Cotonou quarantine station,
but following the only death occurring among them, I performed the autopsy
which gave us the assurance that this was neither yellow fever nor ictero-
hemorrhagic fever.
